Flagler Street, EC 3603, Miami, Florida 33174 17 Tel: (305) 348-2825 18 Fax: (305) 348-2802 19 Email: xjin1@fiu.edu 20 21 Yiman Du 22 Department of Civil Engineering 23 Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China 24 Email: ymducp@gmail.com 25 26 * Corresponding author 27 28 29 30 TRB 16-2284 31 Word Count: 5500+2000 (4 tables and 4 figures) = 7500 32 33 2 Lavasani, Jin and Du ABSTRACT 1 This paper presents the effort in developing a market penetration model for autonomous vehicle 2 technology adoption, based on similar technologies and previous trends in the United States. 3 Generalized Bass diffusion models are developed, based on data from previous technologies, 4 including sales and price data on conventional automobiles and hybrid electric vehicles, and the 5 usage of internet and cellphones. Based on the adoption patterns of previous technologies, two 6 values representing the innovation factor (risk taking capacity) and the imitation factor (culture 7 and lifestyle preferences) are selected for AV market penetration. In addition, external variables 8 such as the price of the AVs relative to conventional vehicles, and economic wealth are 9 incorporated into the model. The market size for AV adoption is determined based on the usage of 10 internet, and household is considered as the unit. Given the uncertainties in market size and price 11 of AVs, sensitivity analysis are also conducted to understand the possible impacts of these factors 12 on user adoption. In general larger market size leads to higher adoption rate, while the initial cost 13 of AVs relative to conventional vehicles does not seem to influence the diffusion process much. 14 This paper contributes to the literature by adding a quantitative analysis of AV market penetration 15 based on past technology adoption experiences. The study results provide valuable insights in 16 terms of the possible market diffusion patterns and the impacts of different factors on user 17 adoption. 18 3 Lavasani, Jin and Du INTRODUCTION 1 Autonomous vehicle (AV) development is a considerable accomplishment of the 21st century. 2 AVs, also known as self-driving vehicles, robotic cars, or driverless cars, are defined as computer 3 equipped vehicles which can be driven and operated without human driver’s active control (1, 2). 4 AVs are capable of fulfilling the main transportation capabilities using information provided by 5 their sensors about the surrounding environment, and do not need connection with infrastructures 6 and other vehicles (3). Automated vehicles may be autonomous (with only vehicle sensors) or may 7 be connected (cars and roadside infrastructure communicate wirelessly). The National Highway 8 Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) defined five levels of automation, starting from level 0 9 which is the basic traditional vehicles with no automation up to level four with full self-driving 10 automation (4). This study considers Level four AVs, when vehicles can perform all driving 11 functions and monitor roadway conditions for an entire trip, and so may operate with occupants 12 who cannot drive and without human occupants (4). 13 Self-driving vehicles may have seemed to be a distant dream several years ago, but manufactures’ 14 prototypes including Google self-driving cars, Mercedes-Benz S 500 Intelligent Drive and Audi 15 A7 Piloted Driving showed that AVs are becoming real now. Google self-driving vehicles have 16 traveled more than 1 million miles from 2009 to May 2015 without human intervention (5) and 17 several other companies plan to release the AVs in the next decade (6-9). On the other hand, 18 legislators are considering bills regarding AV tests and utilizations. Until July 2015, five states of 19 California, Florida, Michigan, Nevada, Tennessee and also District of Columbia have passed laws 20 on testing autonomous vehicles and sixteen other states are considering bills related to autonomous 21 driving in 2015 (10). 22 In light of the fast developing technologies, several studies have been conducted to predict AV 23 adoption rate. Litman (2014) predicted the implementation of AVs based on previous vehicle 24 related technologies (automatic transmission, air bags, hybrid vehicles, subscription vehicle 25 services and vehicle navigation systems) and also fleet turnover rates (11). The study predicted 26 that AVs would be on streets with high cost in 2020s, and it would take up to 2050s to reach 80-27 100% market share. Fagnant and Kockelman (2015) predicted a sooner mass-market presentation 28 start for autonomous vehicles, considering that Nissan and Volvo announced their commercially 29 viable autonomous vehicles in 2020 and five years for price drop down (2). Wallace and Silberg 30 (2012) proposed three possible adoption scenarios, including aggressive adoption, base case 31 adoption and conservative adoption. The adoption scenarios were composed of various elements 32 including cost, technology, and consumer acceptance, etc. (12). 33 Although the above studies all provide valuable perspectives in estimating AV adoption rate, most 34 of them are based on qualitative estimates or focused on the technology aspects only. This paper 35 intends to use a mathematical modeling approach that considers the market size, user adoption 36 behavior, and historical data on the penetration patterns of previous technologies. In this regard, 37 market diffusion models have been proven a powerful tool in predicting the market for new 38 products. Diffusion models can estimate how the new product will penetrate the market and also 39 estimate the market potential for that product. It provides important information for manufacturers 40 4 Lavasani, Jin and Du to control their products based on the market behavior, also it is very critical for policy makers to 1 prepare all the required infrastructures to manage the adoption process. The results of this study 2 can contribute to the literature by providing a mathematical approach to market penetration 3 prediction of AVs, for which the assumptions and inputs of the model can be easily modified and 4 updated based on the latest knowledge of the market and technology progress. 5 The next section summarizes the literature review on the use of diffusion models to predict market 6 penetration for new automobile related technologies, followed by the methodology section that 7 introduces the modeling framework. Model results and sensitivity analysis are presented next, and 8 the last section concludes this study. 9 LITERATURE REVIEW 10 Bass Diffusion Models 11 Generally, diffusion models assume the cumulative sales of a new product over time will be an S-12 shaped curve (Figure 1, up). The curve slope at each time point represents the adoption rate. 13 Adoption rate starts low at the beginning periods of product launch, which reflects consumers’ 14 conservativeness regarding the new product especially if they are not familiar with the product. 15 Gradually, the rate may increase (if the product is successful), as personal recommendations, social 16 and media commercials may persuade followers to use the product. Depending on the product, 17 market saturation will occur in a few months or years when the adoption rate starts to decrease to 18 almost zero. The most popular first-purchase diffusion models in marketing are Bass, Fourt and 19 Woodlock, and Mansfield (13). Among these, the Bass model have been used widely in market 20 penetration forecasting of new products. 21 22 FIGURE 1 Bass model cumulative and non-cumulative adopters curve (14) 23 Bass diffusion models assume adopters of a new innovation are influenced either by mass media, 24 or by word of mouth (13). In other words these two means of communication are the two most 25 important factors on consumers’ acceptance (i.e. purchase the new product or subscribe to the new 26 system). The people who are influenced by mass media are called innovators and the second group 27 are known as imitators in market diffusion model literature. Based on Bass assumption, innovators 28 5 Lavasani, Jin and Du exist in the whole diffusion process while imitators join the market after several sale periods. 1 Figure 1 shows the trend of a nominal product sale during sale periods. Non-cumulative adopters 2 will reach to a maximum point which corresponds to inflection point of cumulative S-shaped 3 curve. 4 The basic Bass model equation, which is derived from a hazard function (the probability that an 5 adoption will occur at time t, given it has not yet occurred), is shown in Eq. 1 (13): 6 𝑛(𝑡) = 𝑑𝑁(𝑡) 𝑑(𝑡) = 𝑝[𝑚 − 𝑁(𝑡)] + 𝑞 𝑚 𝑁(𝑡)[𝑚 − 𝑁(𝑡)] (1) 7 where N(t) is the cumulative number of adopters at time t, m is the potential market size, p and q 8 are coefficients of innovation and imitation, respectively. New registrations for Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG), Compressed Natural Gas 4 (CNG) vehicles, Elective Vehicles (EV) and Hybrid Electric Vehicles (HEV) were used in this 5 study as sales data for new automotive technologies. The study estimated the parameters with 6 varying levels of market size, and found that the innovation coefficient (p) was highly affected by 7 changes in market size while the imitation coefficient (q) was not influenced by market size. The 8 authors found an inverse relationship between assumed market size (M) and innovation coefficient 9 in this study. This will make it very difficult to draw conclusions for the value of (p) when M is 10 fixed, but not precise. This study also provided a fair guidance on using endogenous or exogenous 11 market potential value when applying a Bass model in automotive industry. 12 Cordill (2012) proposed a diffusion model to study the future of HEV market (17). Innovation (p) 13 and imitation coefficient (q) were estimated for three EV technologies of Prius, Hybrid Civic and 14 Ford Escape using 2000-2010 sales data, followed by a survey to develop a model defining 15 important factors affecting consumer’s preference. Respondents who liked to purchase an EV in 16 the near future were classified as innovation group and other participants were classified as 17 imitation group. It was concluded that selected vehicle price, gas saving and price of gas are the 18 three most important factors for both groups, while emission and operation reliability were two 19 other factors affecting the innovators preference and the availability of future tax benefits and 20 vehicle crash report were found to affect the imitators choice. 21 Park et al. (2011) developed a market penetration forecasting model for Hydrogen Fuel Cell 22 Vehicles (HFCV) considering infrastructure and cost reduction effects for Korea (18). Based on 23 their results, HFCV market would be saturated in 2038 in Korea and in 2050 in the US. The 24 parameters of generalized Bass model was estimated based on the historical sales of Prius HEV 25 and its prices in comparison with Toyota Corolla as the representation of conventional vehicles. 26 Another group of market penetration studies used SP surveys and choice modeling approach to 27 estimate diffusion models for new automobile related technologies. Jensen et al. (2014) proposed 28 a forecasting method for EV demand in Denmark using regression method and also diffusion 29 model parameters. The study indicated that alternative specific constant (ASC) of logit models can 30 overshadow the market penetration, hence the authors used adjusted model with diffusion 31 parameters (19). McCoy and Lyons (2014) conducted an agent-based model to simulate market 32 diffusion of EVs in Ireland (20). Analysis of four neighborhoods with different socioeconomic and 33 demographic properties was conducted, and as expected it was found that the wealthier 34 neighborhoods with more homeowners would have much higher adoption level than less wealthy 35 neighborhoods. Brown (2013) simulated the EV diffusion model in Boston using a discrete choice 36 model (21). Results showed that EVs would share 1-22% of the entire vehicle market of Boston in 37 2030. Regarding factors affecting market share, financial incentive availability showed positive 38 effects. 39 7 Lavasani, Jin and Du The geographical transferability of estimated data was also important for market analysis. Jensen 1 et al. (2014) used Norwegian new car registration data from 2003 to 2013 to estimate the EV 2 demand model in Denmark market (19), and used the results directly since lifestyle and economic 3 conditions of the two countries were generally very similar. However Park et al. (2011) which 4 used Japanese sale volume of HEVs to estimate a diffusion model for HFCV in Korea adjusted the 5 imitation parameter based on other previously estimated models in the two countries (18). 6 The Bass model has been widely employed in studies related to new technologies, including those 7 in the automobile industry, yet this approach has not been applied to understand the market 8 adoption of AVs. Considering the advantages of this approach – it uses mathematical models and 9 considers the influence of market size, user behavior and historical data from other products, and 10 the assumptions and inputs can be easily modified and updated to better reflect the latest 11 knowledge of the market and the technology – this study employs this model to study the market 12 penetration pattern of AVs. The details of the methodology and assumptions are described in the 13 following section. 14 METHODOLOGY 15 In this study, a Generalized Bass diffusion modeling approach is used to estimate the market 16 penetration for AVs in the US, since the basic Bass model cannot consider influences of any 17 external variables, i.e. effect of product price during time (18). 18 Historical sales information is required to estimate the generalized Bass model. Since no sales data 19 would be available for brand new products, a similar technology/product would be selected and it 20 is assumed that the new product will resemble the existing product in terms of user adoption 21 pattern. For instance Park et al. (2011) estimated the market diffusion model of HFCVs for Korea, 22 based on the data obtained for HFCVs in Japan with some adjustment to the local market (18). 23 For this study, our estimation is based on the historical sales data for HEV in the US. The 24 assumption is that the market penetration pattern of the AVs would be similar as for the HEVs in 25 the US market. The HEV technology is preferred over other automotive features such as automatic 26 transmission or rear camera, because the latter features only changed a portion of the driving task 27 to a limited degree, and there were not as much resistance when they were first introduced. On the 28 other hand, the first years of HEV deployment have seen conservative and skeptical user adoption, 29 as would be expected for AV adoptions. However, it should also be noted that HEVs would not be 30 as revolutionize as AVs in changing the way people travel. To overcome this limitation, our study 31 also used data from internet and cellphone adoption to adjust the diffusion model, which is 32 discussed in more detail later in this section. 33 Amongst several factors which may affect the adoption behavior, AV technology price, US market 34 technology acceptance rate and economic wealth are considered in this study. To estimate the 35 generalized Bass model, historical price ratio of a representative HEV to a representative 36 conventional vehicle is analyzed. For the technology acceptance taste of US consumers, the 37 diffusion model used information based on internet subscription and cellphone consumption in the 38 8 Lavasani, Jin and Du US market. The reason of studying the internet and cellphone usage, is that these two advanced 1 technologies can be seen as two revolutionary forces in the history of communications, such role 2 we believe AVs will play in the automobile industry. So it is anticipated that the penetration 3 patterns of internet and cellphone usage can reveal some insights to analyze US costumers’ 4 behavior when facing new revolutionary technologies. As for the economic wealth, the US Gross 5 Domestic Product (GDP) per capita (current US$) is used in this study. Several specifications of 6 the models are estimated and compared based on model performances. Then sensitivity analysis is 7 conducted on two important factors which may affect the adoption projection: market size and AV 8 price ratio to conventional vehicle price. 9 To establish the basics for model estimation, it is assumed that the AV market diffusion are similar 10 to the pattern for HEVs. Toyota Prius has been selected as the HEV technology representative vehicle, 12 because it is the best-selling HEV not only in the US, but in the whole world. Prius was launched 13 in 1997 in Japan and three years later in the US. Shortly after, HEV Prius became the best-selling 14 HEV for many years. Prius’s price has not changed for the first three years of sale in the US with 15 a slight drop in the fourth year. Later the price raised in line with general inflation. Toyota Corolla 16 was selected as the representative conventional vehicle, to consider the price ratio factor effect in 17 the generalized Bass model. Corolla was selected because it has the same size and is manufactured 18 by the same company as Prius, but also because of its high sales statistics.
